CIVIL separate application for cassation, are those which terminate the criminal proceedings. A judgment of any other kind can only be brought before the Court of Cassation simultaneously with the judgment on the merits; any application to the said Court made prior to such last mentioned judgment is premature and cannot be entertained. When, therefore, a Court of Appeal, in the exercise of its right of evocation, has ordered the institution of criminal proceedings, and objection is taken to the validity of such proceedings on the ground that the said Court was not duly constituted, the judgment of the Court of Appeal, dismissing such objection, is not open to separate review by the Court of Cassation.
(Cass. 13 January 1900 p. 179).

Cassation (Substantial ground of invalidity):- 1. The action of the civil claimant (partie civile), although of necessity joined to criminal proceedings, is none the less a separate suit, so that a decision upon one of these joint actions cannot be considered as containing an implied decision upon the other. The judgment which does not contain an express and separate decision upon each action, is therefore open to cassation, as being vitiated by a substantial ground of invalidity.

2. The omission by the Court of First Instance to decide upon certain claims raised by the accused cannot be relied upon as a ground for cassation, unless such claims were formally renewed upon appeal.

A person condemned cannot be heard to allege, as a ground for cassation of a judgment, the fact that such judgment omitted to decide upon the appeal of the party intervening as civil plaintiff (partie civile).
(Cass. 30 December 1899, p. 117).
3. The publicity of trial must be proved by a statement in the judgment or in the official record of the trial (feuille d'audience).
The absence of such statement is a substantial ground of invalidity, within the meaning of Art. 220
(3) C. Cr. Pr., and constitutes a reason for cassation.
No other evidence of publicity is admissible.
(Cass. 20 January 1900, p. 149).

4. When a judgment in criminal proceedings states that the accused is not proved to have committed the act upon which the charge is based, the fact that the judgment further contains the erroneous statement, that such an act does not constitute a legal offence, is not a substantial ground of invalidity within the meaning of Art. 220 (3°) C. Cr. Pr., and does not therefore afford a ground for cassation.

As regards the claim of a party intervening as civil plaintiff (partie civile), a declaration, that the accused is not proved to have committed the act in question, constitutes a sufficient statement of the reasons of a judgment dismissing such claim.
(Cass. 20 January 1900, P. 185).

5. A judgment condemning a person for bringing a false charge is null and void, if it does not state that the charge was brought before an administrative or judicial authority. The omission of such statement constitutes a substantial ground of invalidity within the meaning of Art. 220 (39) C. Cr. Pr, and affords a ground for cassation.
(Cass. 20 January 1900, p. 188).

6. The extract of the judgment, which the Registrar is required by Art. 221 C, Cr. Pr. to furnish within eight days from the delivery of judgment to a party who demands the same in view of an application for cassation, must contain the reasons of the judgment. Non-compliance with this requirement constitutes a substantial ground of invalidity. An acquaintance with the reasons of the judgment is indispensable to such party, since the article above cited declares that his application for cassation, which must be made within eighteen days, cannot be entertained unless it states the reasons upon which it is based.
(Cass. 10 March 1900, p. 211).

2. When the Parquet has, after a preliminary examination, ordered the papers in a case to be filed without further proceedings (ordrede classement sans suite), the prosecution cannot be resumed unless fresh charges are adduced.
Since the Decree of 28 May 1895 (Chap. III C.Cr.

Pr.), the effects of such an order are the same as those produced by an order of no probable cause (ordonnance de non-lieu) made by an Examining Magistrate : the cases specified in Art. 15 of the Decree (i.e. those where a warrant of arrest or of apprehension had been issued), are merely inserted as examples, and the principle therein contained is by analogy applicable to all cases where there has been any process of preliminary examination by the Parquet.

This interpretation is rendered necessary, not only by the preliminary discussions concerning the Decree, but also by the anomalies which would result in practice from a contrary interpretation, particularly in the case of a joint prosecution of several offenders, against some of whom alone such warrants as above mentioned had been issued.

From the fact that the order to file is to be regarded as equivalent to an order of no probable cause, it follows also that a civil claimant (partie civile) is thereby debarred from himself directly initiating further proceedings before a Correctional Court, and can take no fresh step unless and until the criminal prosecution is resumed.
(App. 27 December 1899, p. 249).

False Pretences (Obtaining property by).–False statements may sometimes constitute fraudulent contrivances, within the meaning of Art. 312 of the P. C. (obtaining property by false pretences), when made by a person whose position is such that his words inspire exceptional confidence.

The victim of the false pretences is not to be deprived of the protection of the law merely because his dealings with the accused reveal a want of ordinary intelligence. The law owes special protection to persons of a limited and feeble understanding, who require such protection in an exceptional degree.
(App. 3 October 1899, p. 88).

Since the Parquet is now empowered to conduct preliminary examinations, an order to file without further proceedings (ordre de classement sans suite), forms a bar to the reopening of the prosecution (unless fresh charges are adduced ), whenever the action of the Parquet has been that of an Examining Magistrate, that is to say, whenever the Parquet has conducted any kind of preliminary examination. The interpretation of Arts. 14 and 15 of Chap. III, C. Cr. Pr. (Decree 28 May 1895), which would restrict this effect of the order to file to those cases alone where a warrant of apprehension or warrant of arrest had been previously issued, is inadmissible,
6. Arts. 14 and 15 of Chap. III C.Cr.Pr. (Decree 28 May 1895) are evidently to be read together.

It follows that an order to file without further proceedings (ordre de classement sans suite) does not form a bar to the reopening of the prosecution, even where no fresh charges are adduced, unless the order was made in one of the two cases mentioned in Art. 14, that is to say, unless either a warrant of apprehension or a warrant of arrest had been issued.

The object of the legislator, in establishing this restriction, was presumably to afford greater protection to persons who have already been the object of measures of exceptional severity, than to those whose liberty has not yet been interfered with. The argument, that the legislator should have protected all accused persons equally, is irrelevant, since the duty of the Courts is limited to applying the law in the state in which it exists.
(Trib. App. Assiout, 20 May 1900, p. 265).

Forgery:- 1. In deciding upon the existence of the crime or misdemeanour of forgery, it is immaterial whether the fraudulent alteration affects the immediate subject of the document in question or was made for some ulterior purpose.
(App. 11 October 1899, p. 22).

2. Since by Art. 261 of the C. C. C. Pr. seals placed upon official deeds may be used as documents for comparison, the sealing of an official deed with a forged seal constitutes a forgery, even where the signature of such official deed is admittedly genuine.
(App. 11 October 1899, p. 22).
3. The person who fabricates a document in order to establish a disputed claim, is guilty of forgery.

For instance, the fabrication of a letter containing the assent of a person to a judgment against him purporting to be given by default, constitutes a forgery, when a possible prejudice may result therefrom.

The fact that the accused has grounds for contending that the judgment was in reality given after hearing both parties, and that the time for appealing from such a judgment has expired, does not divest the act of its criminal character. There is a possibility of prejudice, so long as the person against whom judgment was given can (upon the ground that the said judgment purports to be by default) contend, either that, not having been executed within six months, it is no longer operative, or that service of notice thereof was not validly effected.
(Apr. 24 October 1899, p. 92).

Jurisdiction:- 1. In actions brought against a person under interdiction who is a native, but whose curator is a foreigner, the native tribunals have jurisdiction, since the nationality of the person under interdiction is alone to be considered.
(Trib. App. Keneh, 31 August 1899, p. 18).

2. By the terms of the Decree of 8 March 1881, water-raising machines, whether movable or stationary, can only be erected in virtue of an authorisation obtained from the Ministry of Public Works, whose decision on the advisability of granting or refusing such authorisation is final. In refusing an application for such an authorisation, the Ministry is acting within the rights conferred by the Decree, and, there being no violation of the law, no action will lie against the Government on the ground of any prejudice which may result to private interests from such refusal.

The Decree of 3 February 1892, relating to the taxation of lands sold by the Government, imposes no obligation on the Government to make canals, or to provide in any way whatsoever for the irrigation of the lands sold, but on the contrary obliges the owners to the payment of the taxes without condition or reserve, even though the land in question remains uncultivated. In taking measures for the forcible collection of such taxes, the Government exercises a right unconditionally conferred by the Decree; accordingly no action will lie against it on this ground, even though it is alleged that the cultivation of the land is impossible owing to the action of the Government itself in refusing permission to erect a machine necessary for its irrigation, if such refusal was made in virtue of powers conferred by the law.
(App. 11 January 1900, p. 154).

When the true value of immovable property forming the subject of an action is stated in the deed, and it has not been proved that such statement was made with intent to defraud the treasury or to prejudice third parties, the question of jurisdiction is to be determined in accordance with such value.

Consequently, the method of valuation indicated in the J. T. (multiplication by 20 of the amount of the tax due to the State) is only applicable where the true amount in dispute does not thus appear from the deed.
(Trib. App. Cairo, 5 February 1898, p. 13).

2. By virtue of Art. 28 0. D. and Art. 143 C. C. the Native Courts have power to set aside a transaction by which a person, subsequeutly to the promulgation of the Native Codes, has founded a Wakf so as to defeat the rights of his creditors.

And since laws relating to procedure are retrospective the Native Courts have also jurisdiction to try an action in which creditors claim to set aside a Wakf founded under similar conditions prior to the publication of the said Codes. In this latter case, the Court will set aside the transaction, if according to the law in force at the time of such transaction a half founded so as to defeat creditors could on that ground be set aside.
The Muhammadan Law, according to the opinion generally accepted, allows that a Wakf founded under such conditions may be set aside to an extent proportional to the amount of the debt.
(App. 5 January 1899, P 191).
3. The fact that a Court has no jurisdiction to try the claim against a surety brought in as third party, in no way affects its jurisdiction as regards the principal claim.

In particular, when the parties to the principal claim are all natives, and one of them brings in as third party a surety who is a foreigner, the jurisdiction of the Court is not ousted as regards the principal claim, but only as regards the claim against the surety. (App. 1 June 1899, p. 103).

4. When a creditor sues one of the heirs of his deceased debtor for payment by such heir of his proportionate part of the debt, if the whole original debt exceeded 10,000 P.T. and the defendant disputes the existence of such original debt, the jurisdiction of the Summary Court is ousted, even though the amount claimed in the action does not exceed 100,000 P.T. For the action concerns a “part” of a disputed debt, within the meaning of Art. 30.
C.C. C. Pr., and such disputed debt exceeds the limits of jurisdiction of a Summary Court.

The rule, however, is different, and the Summary Court has jurisdiction, if, by reason of payments previously made, the amount remaining due on the original debt no longer exceeds 10,000 P.T.; since in this case the sum in question is a “ balance" and not a “part” of a disputed debt, within the meaning of the article above referred to.
(Trib. App. Tantah, 25 January 1900, p.195).

JURISDICTION

Jurisdiction (of Criminal Courts) :- 1. Since the legislature has established certain excuses in law, and has provided a reduced punishment, for cases where such excuses are proved, this reduced punishment, of which the limits are thus fixed by the law, is a “penalty provided by law.” When therefore a person under fifteen years of age is prosecuted for misdemeanour, the penalty which determines what Court has jurisdiction to hear the case on appeal brought by the State Representative (Art. 175, note, C.Cr.Pr.) [Decree 26 June, 1895], is the reduced penalty applicable under Art. 62 P.C.

The fact that the existence of the excuse in law may eventually be disprored is not a reason for bringing the matter before the Court which would have jurisdiction to hear the appeal in the absence of such excuse ; for in deciding before what Court an action is to be brought, the facts of the case are to be considered as they appear before the hearing is commenced, without prejudice however to the duty of the Court to decline jurisdiction subsequently if necessary.
(Cass. 31 December 1898, p. 275).

2. Under C. Cr. Ir. Art. 171, a Criminal Court has, in the case of an acquittal, a general power of considering the claim for damages made by the person intervening as civil plaintiff, as well as that of the person acquitted. But the claim of such civil plaintiff can only be considered, if the act wbich caused him prejudice appeared bona fide to constitute a criminal offence (the object of the institution of criminal proceedings not being merely to exclude the jurisdiction of the civil Courts), and provided also that the determination of the existence or amount of prejudice would not entail lengthy proceedings.
(Cass. 28 January 1899, P. 83).
3. A Criminal Court has no jurisdiction, in the case of an acquittal, to decide upon a claim for damages of a purely civil character.
(Trib. App. Cairo, 11 January 1900, p. 259).

4. A Criminal Court has jurisdiction to decide upon the existence of a contract, whenever the proof of such contract is necessary to establish the criminal charge. But parol evidence is admissible in those circumstances alone in which it would be admissible before a Civil Court.

When therefore a person, prosecuted under Art. 315 P. C. for fraudulent conversion as bailee of a document of title relating to a sum exceeding 1,000 P.T., disputes the existence of the bailment, parol evidence cannot be adduced on this point unless such a course would be permissible before a Civil Court. The fact that the bailee is the husband of the bailor's sister, does not of itself form such an obstacle to obtaining documentary evidence as is referred to in Art. 215 C. C.
(Trib. App. Cairo, 11 January 1900, p.259).

5. The offence of bringing a false charge, contained in a written document, is not completed until such document reaches the representative of the judicial or administrative authority. Consequently the Court within whose district the residence of such representative, where he received the document addressed to him, is situated, has jurisdiction to try the case, as being the Court of the place where the offence was committed.
(Trib. App. Tantah,13 February 1900, P 151).
6. According to Art. 173 C. Cr. Pr. a Correctional Tribunal, before which a prosecution for misdemeanour is pending, is bound to decline jurisdiction, whenever there is a primá-facie case of crime.

Such a Tribunal, when once it has declared that the case is primá-facie one of crime, has no jurisdiction to investigate the merits. Such jurisdiction belongs exclusively to the Criminal Court, in virtue of Arts. 210 follg. C. Cr. Pr.

7. In the case of a person under 15 years of age accused of misdemeanour, the reduced penalty alluded to in Art. 62 P.C. is the penalty provided by the law." within the meaning of the Decree of 26 June 1895 (see Art. 175, note C. C. Pr.). The appeal, therefore, of the State Representative in such a case is to be brought before the Court of Appeal only when the maximum penalty which can thus be applied exceeds one year's imprisonment.

8. Under Art. 171 C. Cr. Pr. a Correctional Tribunal has jurisdiction, even when the accused is acquitted, to decide upon the claim for damages brought by the person intervening as civil claimant (partie civile). But this jurisdiction should be declined : a) If the act which formed the subject of the prosecution did not appear bona fide to constitute a legal offence, the sole object of the civil claimant being to exclude the jurisdiction of the Civil Court. b) If the existence of prejudice cannot be proved or the damages assessed without lengthy proceedings.

En dehors de ces cas, le parquet reste libre de revenir sur son ordre de classement, même s'il n'y a pas de charges nouvelles.
2° L'ordre de classement sans suite fait par le parquet après instruction, fait toujours obstacle à la reprise de l'action publique s'il n'y a pas de charges nouvelles.
Depuis le décret du 28 Mai 1895 (C. I. C.

Chap. III), un tel ordre a les mêmes effets que l'ordonnance de non-lieu d'un juge d'instruction ; les cas de mandats d'arrêt ou d'amener visés par l'art. 15 du dit décret ne sont qu'énonciatifs et le principe doit être étendu, par analogie, à tous les cas où il y a eu des actes d'instruction.

Cette interprétation s'impose à raison des travaux préparatoires du décret, ainsi que des anomalies qui résulteraient de l'interprétation contraire, notamment en cas de pluralité d'accusés dont quelques-uns seulement ont été l'objet d'un mandat d'arrêt ou d'amener.

De ce que l'ordre de classement doit être assimilé à une ordonnance de non-lieu, il résulte également que la partie civile ne peut, après un tel ordre, saisir directement le tribunal correctionnel, mais doit attendre la reprise de l'action publique.

En exigeant le paiement de ces impôts, le Gouvernement exerce un droit qui lui est conféré sans restrictions par la loi. Participation criminelle. — Lorsque plusieurs personnes en ont attaqué plusieurs autres à la suite d'un concert préalable et que quelques-unes de ces dernières ont été tuées et d'autres blessées plus ou moins grièvement, il n'y a qu'un seul délit et tous les participants à l'infraction sont passibles des peines prévues par une même disposition pénale. En l'absence de concert préalable, au contraire, par exemple en cas de rixe spontanée et imprévue, chacun des agresseurs n'est responsable que de son propre fait et du mal qu'il a causé par ses actes.
Dans le cas de l'art. 215, le concert préalable s'entend de la commune volonté de donner des coups.
C'est le fait de donner volontairement des coups qui forme l'élément constitutif du délit, le fait d'occasionner la mort n'étant qu'une circonstance qui en aggrave le caractère.
